name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: Big political news keeps breaking, but almost a million Americans have already voted. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, we look at what effect the upcoming presidential debates could have on the election.
https://t.co/9f2kWjST1Y

name: NPR
text:
If she's confirmed, Amy Coney Barrett would be a sixth conservative vote on the Supreme Court ‚Äî making it plausible that there will be a majority to overturn Roe v. Wade outright.
https://t.co/hAcu4Hlgbu

name: NPR
text:
NEW: More than 1 million people worldwide have died from COVID-19 ‚Äî a sobering milestone reached just 9 months after the first reported fatality in China. The trend remains worrisome in these 5 nations.
https://t.co/J1YGBMDAAY

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking the global spread of COVID-19. Explore our charts for a country-by-country breakdown of cases.
https://t.co/xEfsLJrHAh

name: NPR
text: The ‚Äòpandemic pod‚Äô experiment has built a sense of community among parents juggling the demands of work and virtual school. It‚Äôs also raised equity concerns. (@WHYY) https://t.co/zup0kSVPhy

name: NPR
text:
üì∫üçÇ Looking for something to watch this fall?

Luckily, there are still lots of good options. Here are some of the best shows coming out this season, according to four NPR critics.
https://t.co/YOLb2oiQkW

name: NPR
text:
More than a hundred teachers in Little Rock, Ark., refused to show up for in-person classes Monday, saying they're concerned about COVID-19 and are only willing to teach remotely.

The district has threatened to fire them.
https://t.co/Sib6uRZrxe

name: NPR
text:
A magistrate ruled that Uber can keep operating in London, under strict supervision, after the court found the ride-sharing company had tightened its policies to address unauthorized driver fraud.
https://t.co/VtkC74B4qj

name: NPR
text:
"I think the best evidence of her position on Roe v. Wade is that President Trump has said he will only appoint justices who are committed to reversing Roe, and there's no reason not to believe him," one attorney and bioethicist says of Amy Coney Barrett.
https://t.co/xCYVeMI5Nr

name: NPR
text:
President Trump deducted $70,000 for the cost of his haircuts and hairstyling during the making of The Apprentice, according to tax documents obtained by The New York Times.
https://t.co/T0jVgqX11T

name: NPR
text:
The House last week passed Savanna's Act, a bill that requires the Justice Department to strengthen training, coordination and data collection in cases of murdered or missing Native Americans.
https://t.co/dHELBMFUuw

name: NPR
text:
Only 5% of books published for young readers are by or about Latinx people, according to one analysis. But a team of writers, editors and publishing agents have set out to change that.
https://t.co/pYfmicBC1h

name: NPR
text:
No, you can't deduct your next visit to a salon or barbershop.

The U.S. Tax Court has repeatedly ruled that the costs of maintaining an appealing appearance are not deductible ‚Äî even for public personalities.
https://t.co/zYxOKuxX4n

name: NPR
text:
President Trump vowed to name Supreme Court justices who'd vote to overturn Roe v. Wade. Activists say Amy Coney Barrett fits that mold. Her history as a federal judge offers clues of her views.
https://t.co/ZnveYvMU5N

name: NPR
text:
Since May, Palestinian authorities have refused to register newborns with Israeli occupation authorities. 

It's part of a campaign to defy Israel's grip on Palestinian life ‚Äî and it means 70,000 babies are unable to travel outside Gaza and the West Bank. https://t.co/rqxldkop6d

name: NPR
text: A survey of 17 cities found more than 50,000 pandemic-related eviction filings. Housing advocates worry that increased housing instability will lead to more COVID-19 and other illnesses. https://t.co/JFgn94rb9G

name: NPR
text: The Navy is naming a supercarrier after an enlisted sailor ‚Äì and an African American.  Doris "Dorie" Miller was a hero at Pearl Harbor, and a key figure in the rise of the civil rights movement. https://t.co/rINu34F0cf

name: NPR
text: COVID-19's economic aftershocks have hit the hospitality industry especially hard. Experts say it may not return to pre-pandemic levels until 2023, as hospitality workers bear the brunt of this long downturn. https://t.co/gQ6DMOku0H

name: NPR
text: The first presidential debate is high stakes. Can Trump avoid the sitting-president first-debate slump? Does Biden come across competently? And how personal will it get? https://t.co/27ul1HrHrU

name: NPR
text:
In the U.S., more than 600,000 cases of children with COVID-19 have been reported, according to a survey from the American Academy of Pediatrics. 

But researchers say severe illness from the virus is rare among kids.
https://t.co/QFx7rHZ5xu

name: NPR
text:
The recording of grand jury proceedings in the Breonna Taylor case will be released this week.

The unusual step comes after a juror disputed the Kentucky attorney general's explanation for why no charges were filed directly related to Taylor's killing.
https://t.co/8Uoz4zTAVX

name: NPR
text:
More than 7.1 million people in the U.S. have been infected with the coronavirus so far.

Here's how much cases are up compared to 2 weeks ago:

üìà Utah: +107%
üìà South Dakota: +92%
üìà Wisconsin: +84%
üìà North Dakota: +35%
üìà Iowa: +38%
https://t.co/NDzkwtiofa

name: NPR
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is warning Democrats that they must win ‚Äî not just the House, but a majority of each state delegation ‚Äî¬†in case the House is called upon to decide the presidential election in January. https://t.co/1lFq9Odt8S

name: NPR
text: This was Bowen Yang‚Äôs answer when @samsanders asked him what he thinks was his most absurd moment filming Saturday Night Live skits at home earlier this year. Watch the extended interview at https://t.co/H7Ca8tYbX5 https://t.co/zfhkFUii1L

name: NPR
text:
Artists Sam Lavigne and Tega Brain have turned 200,000 GoFundMe comments into artwork.

"We're thinking about it as an archive of well wishes, but an archive that shouldn't exist, that exists because of a terrible structural inequality that we all face." https://t.co/QgNa6QLI4D

name: NPR
text:
A grand jury has declined to indict Jack Wilson ‚Äî the volunteer security guard who shot and killed a gunman that opened fire in a Texas church last winter, killing two congregants.
https://t.co/PHhQHn4chV

name: NPR
text:
1/ The pandemic means food insecurity in the U.S. is growing.
In 2019, 10.5% of all U.S. households experienced food insecurity at some point. During the pandemic, that number has doubled, researchers say.
https://t.co/lii9b0qnFR

name: NPR
text: 2/ The hunger rate in small towns around the country is slightly higher than in urban areas. Lexington, Neb., is one of the many rural communities that has long dealt with food insecurity, and the pandemic created new challenges. https://t.co/EMbn6RuyJ9

name: NPR
text: 3/ Food insecurity happens in wealthy areas, too. In Montgomery County, Md., drivers line up early for food distribution every week. For some, being food insecure is a source of shame. https://t.co/tu7oXuaIu7

name: NPR
text: 4/ Ja Nelle Pleasure says there‚Äôs ‚Äúnot a belt to tighten.‚Äù About 25% of white families with children say they‚Äôre struggling to afford food. For Black families with children, it‚Äôs 40%. https://t.co/nXIRbGiA4V

name: NPR
text:
In an interview, Sen. Ted Cruz says he doesn't think President Trump's nominee, Amy Coney Barrett, should recuse herself from a decision if the election ends up at the Supreme Court.
https://t.co/yv6NlDWoxy

name: NPR
text:
The Tennessee Titans and Minnesota Vikings are suspending all in-person club activity after the Titans announced three players and five other personnel tested positive for the coronavirus.
https://t.co/aC8K1LmJsJ

name: NPR
text:
Donald Trump deducted $70,000 for the cost of hairstyling during "The Apprentice," tax documents obtained by NYT show.

But the U.S. Tax Court has repeatedly ruled the costs of maintaining one's appearance aren't deductible ‚Äî even for public personalities.
https://t.co/wvrczkg9CO

name: NPR
text:
One of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's signature collars ‚Äî white lace with a thick gold edge and pearl clasp ‚Äî will go on permanent display at the Museum of the Jewish People in Tel Aviv when it reopens.
https://t.co/kLLfKFhDyR

name: NPR
text:
The Good Ones were suppose to play a Tiny Desk concert in May of this year, but the world had other plans. 

The duo was still able to perform this recording, even with recent flooding in Rwanda.  https://t.co/IhzYHKsPM8

name: NPR
text:
The ruler of Kuwait, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, who was known as a master diplomat who tried to mediate disputes in the volatile Gulf region, has died at the age of 91.
https://t.co/taDcn22V5J

name: NPR
text:
The August Complex Fire in California, currently the largest fire in the state, grew almost 60,000 acres in a single day, Cal Fire reports. Firefighters are struggling to battle several fast-spreading blazes.
https://t.co/SQ7yI9eMF6

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden and Kamala Harris have released their 2019 tax returns. 

Biden's return shows a taxable income of $944,737 and a federal tax bill of $299,346. He has now released 22 years of returns, his campaign said.
https://t.co/8G5Gd3k7TV

name: NPR
text:
A recent CDC report confirms what many public health experts have been warning: Coronavirus cases in young adults lead to infections in older and more vulnerable people ‚Äî who are more likely to be hospitalized and die from COVID-19.
https://t.co/r89dOJrTWj

name: NPR
text:
A lawyer for Michael Flynn, the former national security adviser, said in court Tuesday that she briefed President Trump and one of his lawyers on the status of Flynn's criminal case in the past 2 weeks.
https://t.co/8hX52MRcQB

name: NPR
text: Andrew Weissmann was one of the lead prosecutors on special counsel Robert Mueller's team. In his new book, Where Law Ends, Weissmann looks back on where the Mueller investigation succeeded ‚Äî and where it fell short. https://t.co/LqktyYeRu0

name: NPR
text: The coronavirus did not create the struggles that working mothers face daily. But it has exacerbated them and made them more visible, forcing women of all income levels to make hard choices. https://t.co/SWcpWst9pY

name: NPR
text:
In India, Amnesty International says it has been forced to lay off staff and bring work to a grinding halt ‚Äî citing "an incessant witch-hunt" by India's Hindu nationalist government against some human rights organizations.
https://t.co/s0f8qwy1Gl

name: NPR
text: Daniel Prude's family knew he was having a psychiatric crisis and needed care. A few hours after his release from Strong Memorial Hospital, an encounter with police proved fatal. https://t.co/nri4ViSLEt

name: NPR
text: RT @npratc: The world is waiting for a coronavirus vaccine. And while multiple trials are in their final phase, we're probably still closer to the beginning of the pandemic than the end. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, we take a look at the timeline. https://t.co/qTf5z7EMch
